However, where Mattel is falling flat on its face is with its gross-margin percentage, which stands now at 59% compared to a year ago's 64%. Net income is down 40% during the first quarter.
The importance of gross margin
When trying to figure out a company's fiscal health, gross margin percentage is where you should look first; it's what is ultimately left after all other selling, general & administrative (SG&A) expenses are factored in. endeared himself to the Democratic establishment, winning applause at President Obama's convention acceptance speech and earning plaudits for his role in reforming New York's elite prosecuting corps.
But Vance is a prosecutor in a very unsettled time. As prosecutors across the country answer to a movement with deep roots criticizing them for too often treating low-income people badly — and even for compounding racial injustice — the Manhattan DA is underlining how radical change in the ranks can be impossible to fully achieve. Vance represents the urban movement for progressive prosecutorial reform — and its traditional political advocates like Barack Obama when he was president.
Critics, however, say that as a black prosecutor in what's formally a progressive district, Vance's campaign has raised questions about how just, and to whom, his reforms will apply.

The club has specified a yearly donation will go to the VRA so they can purchase the biomes needed to reactivate their telematics program. This program recompenses their volunteers with fuel vouchers and paid annual leave - meaning they continue to come and help when they would like and it's no longer penalising them by working on community service holidays like the 25th of January.

professionals in predicting subsequent events and plotting likely responses based on specific decision options. Decision trees, also known as classifying trees or branching rules, can be a valuable addition to a manager's toolbox.
To create a decision tree, a business professional starts with the end goal on a branch, such as the Washington, D.C. area. Opposing branches on a tree represent errors or different paths at the end, with a minimal representation of each choice. When the branches end, they interconnect to show the options a manager would assess after making decisions on certain choices. At best, only 50 percent of the time can it list the best outcome, even after researching the entire tree's options. Classifying trees can reflect the unknown in a bottomless pit, with all options leading to the unknown situation.

ongoing war of political terms in state political circles.
The first question involves a U.S. Department of Commerce Bureau of the Census memo dealing with political recognition for the years ahead. Census elections are important, of course – they determine representation in federal law-making circles –but they nonetheless require a seemingly arcane level of political detail mixing national party rules and state law into canvases that’d make Jackson Pollock bark.
In short, Congress sets rules for the upcoming election schedule; for most states, it comes two years and a week after a Fourth of July. Then individual states decide whether and how to count their legislative districts when it comes time to redraw them. Then states decide whether they have primaries or caucuses. Finally states decide when and where to hold their general elections.
All those folks make calls with important consequences for the U. S. Constitution’s Norm of No Precedent.

You never have to connect any peripherals or devices into your phone. Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America, maintaining his focus on the need to change national politics and governance after years in which partisan clashes and special interests trumped all other concerns. COUNCIL BLUFFS — The Marshalltown Community College baseball team built a nine-run lead and held on to salvage a split against NJCAA Division I No. 12 Iowa Western in Saturday’s Iowa Conference doubleheader.
Brad Hayden (So./Manhattan, Kan.) drove in a pair of runs for the Spartans with a 3-for-6 performance that included a home run and four runs scored on the day. Matt LaBarbera went 3-for4 to help MCC build an 11-5 lead after four innings.
The Spartans only yielded eight hits over 6 IP was enough to create more than enough distance. Iowa Western finally tacked on three runs off its junior varsity team in bottom of the fifth before MCC was able to head to the paddock where coach Dave Doerffler shook off his first loss as head coach 17-4 last May.
It was just enough for the team from Council Bluffs, Iowa to win its fifth straight.
For more on MCC sports, go online to www.marshalltown.edu/athletics.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual percentage change of income, the general government balance at market prices, plus other income receipts (interest and social security contributions) plus expenditure less payments for acquisition less disposal of non-produced assets, both equivalent income based concepts measured in percent of quarter aggregates.
General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) measures the percentage change of government income less gross investment against non-investment general government spending. Supply shocks, asset income (foreign investment earnings), and the trend change over time of various categories of government spending and revenues are excluded.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely. Ireland ranked highest for maternal mortality with 3.7 deaths per 100,000 births, while the US did slightly better with 2.2 deaths per 100,000. The truth is that America’s rate is almost double the global average, at five points higher, and even though it is continuing to drop, it is going in the wrong direction.
The women’s group Amnesty International made this point clear when plastering subway cars and train station in Brooklyn with signs criticising the US maternal mortality rate. Though putting parented-parenthood back on track are the key requisites: giving women abortion support without judgment, paid parental and birth leave. WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate Earth cousin with about the right conditions for life last week, researchers were pushing in a separate direction – the carbon.
The hunt for a so-called “carbon-rich” oddball, dubbed GJ 411b, is suggesting that water is not the only thing in the universe that may put a planet on life’s side in the oceans-versus-lifelessness contest.
“To be habitable, instead of water, it could be carbon, as in the animal life forms on Earth,” says the University of Wisconsin-Madison’s Yanka Barbuanova, one of the leading scientists involved in GJ 411b’s detection. Carbon, she notes, “makes the planet earthlike”.

Mattel has a plan for the rest of the year, but it seems to be playing a shorter game.
According to its most recent earnings release, Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) reported numbers that were worse than expected by analysts.
Revenue for the first quarter ended March 31 is up 16% over last year for Mattel, as sales were clearly helped out by the success of the Disney/Pixar film Cars 2. However, where Mattel is falling flat on its face is with its gross-margin percentage, which stands now at 59% compared to a year ago's 64%. Net income is down 40% during the first quarter.

When trying to figure out a company's fiscal health, gross margin percentage is where you should look first; it's what is ultimately left after all other selling, general & administrative (SG&A) expenses are factored in. Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, evergreen foliage to 1.2 m in winter.
In response to the stimulus of cool and warm day temperatures it produces harmless white starry flowers covering the dark green leaves into October.
From the highveld mountains of South Africa comes Daisen’s second burgundy-leaved Diascia.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Trinity College, Dublin, and then the following four weeks had free time. For my last week, I nearly went to Paris. But during my Shabbos visits with my cousin’s hosts in Ireland, I heard we too should spend the following week in Paris, and I decided to meet them there.
I caught a flight from Dublin to Heathrow Airport on Monday, June 28, 1993. The British were still on British time; that means your day begins at 9:00 am. So instead of waking up at 3:00 am, we had to rise at 2:30. And right after we landed, we headed to Lady Agnes for Shabbos, a pricey hotel not far from the airport. They were expecting me.
Every male guest was invited to Reb Dovid Kassoff’s table Friday night. He seemed older to me than he was.

SANTA FE SPRINGS – A 17-year-old boy died and two men were wounded but expected to survive after a car-to-car shooting on the 5 Freeway late Wednesday in Santa Fe Springs, police said.
The teen was in the back seat of a car when three gunmen approached the vehicle at about 8:30 p.m. in the eastbound lanes and started shooting, said police Sgt. James Hinkle.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come only through a profound overhaul of society, an expansion of public services, a rewriting of property rights and an end to private profit.
Conventional eco-capitalism is adept at making sure that the profits of its new growth models stay in the hands of owners of production and extraction firms.
Shell may well promote the notion of hydraulic fracturing as “the next natural gas revolution” but its methane emissions are three times those of coal.
Exxon’s new technologies are believed by many to be a boon to global warming. Actually, their extraction of methane deep below the oil deposits is contributory, by leaking billions of tons of methane. Or take the case of electric cars, which may well save money on fossil fuels, but also exacerbate global warming, for their batteries generate acute environmental problems

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consistency
To be talented? To be consistent? To anticipate? To innovate? To taste like home? To satisfy like home?
To keep people coming back, you've simply got to learn how. Professionalism is about humility and pride.
To become nothing but a chef is to sandpaper the human out of people.
I try to find the paths between, where life spills over and one head isn't enough to contain my emotions.
Fear of losing my family will keep me producing. Fear and any kind of reprimand, will motivate me further. And failure is the best form of ambition, making contradiction and dissonance, exploring what's interesting beyond technocracy.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that has been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered a series of state restrictions last year because of the drought.
One of those was ending the delivery of free shower-head replacements that the state provided to water districts because the drought could hamper their ability to deliver. Water conservation efforts will still be recommended.
More than two dozen reservoirs think they still need more water to be drought free at more than 80 per cent capacity, which needs 103 percent of average. The target is needed for Shasta Lake.
The remaining restrictions on surface water appropriations will remain. The restrictions also cover runoff water, stored ground water and water conveyance, and may prevent water from being used from irrigation of agricultural land. Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference.
About 80 per cent of the PC market runs an older version of Windows that doesn't implement native content protection, which some customers think prevents music, movies, software, and individual rights management (IRM)-protected business documents and programs from working, even as audio frequencies higher the listening range bleed through systems.
"The harmful effects of CPP's are largely anecdotal, but then spending your whole day fiddling with gimmicky workaround techniques isn't any way to enjoy PC multimedia or other content" said Gutmann, chief privacy officer at New Zealand's Canterbury University. He said CPPs merely prevent "quite pointless security application from interfering with purchaseable content" and make unsuspecting consumers pay for admission to files.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers grow well in the course of spring, summer, and the beginning of autumn in a dry period garden that has rich soil, with some water. Peppers generally take a couple of months to mature. Trees or shrubs are required to grow them well, as in a back garden. One or more cultivars of jalapeno peppers ar e required for pollination, when they are grown together.
Pole and bush forms exist, so choose carefully between them depending on the size your intended garden. You cannot harvest jalapenos that are still unripe for cooking if they are small, because they’re hot. They need enough sugar to really be juicy and fleshy. There’s little need to shell them when they are hot, dry out, crunchy and crispy. They’re typically seeded or with no seed at all. A number of varieties exist and they are available in gro

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Coming functions will include location-based search and instant-messaging services, experts such as Gartner Inc’s Ranjit Atwal told Reuters in an interview. Mobile phones could eventually even help people decide which friends to go out with — or how long to sit on a bus stop during a rainstorm.
GPS-enabled mobile phones will be common, he says: A report out last week estimated over half of new phones shipped by the end of this year will be GPS units; a shift that could increase shipments by 40 percent or $12.2 billion by 2013.
With this trend, people will store and update a GPS-based list of their trusted friends, Atwal said, and recommendations about who to meet from this data would be their answer anytime they want to make new friends.
One application for this is cellphone-based meet-up groups

I’m not one to adhere rigidly to the idea of drinking seasonally: reds when it’s cold, whites and rosés when the weather heats up. This is textbook nonsense that makes it difficult – though there may be exceptions – to know ahead of time under what conditions a wine is going to be excellent. For instance, many cold-climate reds that might be a cliched “summer mate” would in actuality go wonderfully with comforting fare like chicken and turkey. Shouldn’t the main thing be that there are delicious beverages of every type (and a hierarchy of greatness) to enjoy during the colder months of the month?
That said, it’s good to know what foods and occasions match well with which beverages, even if it is more an idea than an airtight rule. Martin Scorsese's "Silence" may have been his 28-year-old passion project, but it was mostly known for the years it complicated his working relationship and partnerships with both Robert De Niro and Leonardo DiCaprio.
In May 2013, De Niro recounted that Scorsese told him he was willing to pick up a whole new career if he insisted he wasn't enjoying it anymore. After that, the Oscar-winning actor revealed, the director began to collaborate less frequently, with one notable exception: "Ciao Italia", which debuted that year.
De Niro made his remarks while being interviewed at the 2013 Festival de Cannes.
Once DiCaprio also made his comments public, the director began to insist the matter had long been put to rest, even enlisting his star to help him explain that "the book created a beautiful cinematic language for [the film] that just danced in my mind," Scorsese told HitFix earlier this week. Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept here in Concord in the 1890s. And right now meteorologists are telling us this is the driest July we’ve had in 100 years. Thus the current drought.
Um, right. Concord’s climate is influenced by the Great Lakes system which covers about a fifth of the US and two-thirds of our surface, and thus right now is likely the wettest place in America. We haven’t had an El Nino in years, we are getting rained out of a feast for the storm-chasers, and it’s the coldest July since well before Lucy & Charlie met on Sitcom Street, so something about it smells fishy.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 174.
For Americans with adjusted gross income of $200,000 or more the audit rate this year will be one out of every 40.
For taxpayers with over $10 million of adjusted gross income the audit rate is estimated to be about 17%. That means if an individual earns $10 million or more that person will have a roughly 17% chance of getting audited.
Congress will not rush to fix this. Few even care as long as their own constituents are getting audited. In the US the politicians don’t fear you as much as you fear the politician. Still, it is well worth considering how much we depend upon this government and how often they abuse it.

COLUMBIA, SC (WIS) - James Robert Thomason has owned his liquor store since 2002.
Right now, Thomason’s Wine and Liquor, just like any other liquor store, can only sell wine and beer drank with food. But Thomason thinks he can change that by having annoying neighbors only file more noise complaints.
For the most part people at Thomason’s worry that noise issues will dampen the atmosphere since music can be heard outside, but Nev Randall isn’t home during the day.
“I’m not home often,” said Nev Randall manager of the Regalia Bedford, one of multiple companies that uses plants on two side streets close to Thomason’s. Randall said it’s almost never a problem since they file as much as 25 noise complaints a day in the afternoons, so when that month is over, everything looks in the clear. “They just get so high speed on one street,” Randall said.
But how does this noise affect the business?

Music to be performed includes Vivaldi’s concerto in D for violin, an Irish theme from Nicholas Lÿndhurst and the famous ‘Jupiter’the finale of Holst’s The Planets.
Blackpool Symphony Orchestra was founded over 100 years ago and is based at Stanley High School. For more information about BSO, visit www. blackpoolorchestra.org.uk, find on Facebook or follow on Twitter.

Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton had just declared victory in the Nevada caucuses when most campaign reporters heard Jeffrey Berman’s voice for the first and only time.
Berman, Sen. Barack Obama’s campaign spokesman, was on the phone with a reporter from The Globe as Clinton was almost finished taking questions following her victories in Nevada and South Carolina.
“How are you doing, Jeff?” Asked The Globe reporter.
“I’m doing great, I’m just fine,” Berman replied.
It would be the final smile the campaign staffer would ever get, in life or beyond. About 40 hours after his reaction to the last human-like experience his and his closest campaign colleagues had ever experienced, Jeffrey Berman was cut in half by a train.
An Associated Press story Sunday provided the most chilling details of the 35 year old’s slow death that began on the morning of the Nevada caucus.

KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original Balinese and others who have also immigrated here historically, have only sparse knowledge of their roots, but now many on the islands are have taken a more recent step, returning home for rest.Helm
Rudi Kritikan said his grandfather arrived here from Bali when he was 10 years old. He says the family story tells how they crossed the open water on sticks and pet dogs, arriving in south Kei Kecil. “Only the dads and mums remain from that generation and the others died,” he said, adding: “I have heard that from the grandfather also, that maybe there are still some there.”Vehicles

I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014. In a nutshell, SB 837 makes methods to certify private day care workers "voluntary." I want to underscore the word "voluntary," because it's the operative word.
SB 837 will force certification of the 4,000 employees in California who work in licensed preschools. We can't avoid it. Under current state law, the lack of certification could result in shutting down more than 250,000 healthy families. State laws don't allow for that kind of cataclysm on our children, teachers, and the larger community.

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, the single largest source of the state's tax collections.
A day earlier, the governor had flatly rejected a plan by the state Senate for business property taxes and floated his own, broader market-tax plan meant to raise collections. In his more aggressive social media presence since winning a 3rd term, the governor dug in for a long fight to lower taxes for all Texans, along with improved state school finance.
Absent from Abbott’s plans is a focus meant to make property taxes untouchable — by requiring greater local school finance through a separate sales tax.
It appears taxes are unlikely to be lowered this session unless ratings agencies bounce back Texas' credit rating, meaning the state has enough funds to cut here and still spend on flood mitigation and embrace other priorities on Gov. Abbott's list. That is unrelated to property taxes.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat lung and throat infections such as pneumonia and tonsillitis. It can also treat skin and soft tissue infections, and eye infections.
Each white, oval, biconvex capsule imprinted N31 contains clarithromycin 250 mg of clarithromycin, an antimicrobial agent used in the treatment of susceptible infections of the respiratory tract, sinuses, ears and throat (community-acquired pneumonia, pharyngitis, laryngitis, tonsillitis, otitis media) skin, soft tissue, conjunctiva, and bone and joint. Nonmedicinal ingredients: croscarmellose sodium; dibasic calcium phosphate dihydrate; magnesium stearate hydrogenated castor oil

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over time. While most of the research has focused on the surface waters, marine biogeochemists from University of Delaware and the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa are now tracking changes under the surface, along a transect off the Delaware coast.
This story was reprinted with permission from the University of Delaware Office of News & Information.
“The interesting thing about the ocean surface is that CO2 levels are changing, but at the same time there are other chemicals (bicarbonate) that regulate ocean acidity and pH,” said UD oceanographer Amanda Demopoulos of the University's School of Marine Science and Policy and Applied Science program. “CO2 dissolves as bicarbonate. It’s like a balance sheet. Off Delaware, we see tipping points as the ratio becomes small

PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the arrogant high-fliering scientist one might expect to learn of. Morning his father in-law at 29-years old he lived a quiet dignified life until his death in 2010 when he took matter not only into his own hands but also managed not to rock the boat with the rest of Scotland.
Even now his first name ‘Peter’ describes him. An unchanging trait in a man even his wife confessed to have married ‘naked’. A man that once upon a time she said was too reserved to try putting his ideas across at the annual Institute of Physics meeting.
Even if he did come up with an entirely new way of getting at the secrets hidden in space its elusive nature meant it was impossible for him to prove it wrong – that Higgs boson just might in fact be just one type of creation in a multiverse of them.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised (or implied) a ghostly look inside people and other things.
We may not be living in the future yet. But the technology already exists that would give you a x-ray scan of a living, or formerly living, person, body part or thing.
Thanks to the laser crazies. Lasers can shoot peeks a lot more precisely than classic X-ray devices because they can better pinpoint ultra-fine spots without leaving the image looking like a really bad painter was late on a commission. And X-ray cameras remain cheaper and more dependable when it comes to bone scanning.

Alex is IP Australia's first-generation Avcomm-powered online application that manages IP cases before IP Australia, allowing customers to obtain information on applications, appeals, oppositions and ongoing investigations across more than 25 items. In the past, all enquiries had to be handled manually through the telephone, with a call typically handled at a cost of 33 cents per call. Today Alex can answer approximately 60 per cent of the enquiries automatically with the remaining calls handled by IP Australia employees. This transition means that in the first hours following its inception, approximately 86 lives were changed for the better with customers easily, efficiently and quickly obtaining answers to their enquiries.

Increased electronic transactions and interactively managed enquiries instead of answering them all via the phone

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but also develops narrated monologues for exhibits, turret displays, voice overs for the web, touch tables at museums, and oral histiories. Much of these products remain in their "raw" format on the AFHSD website in draft-stage as they await final editing, narration, and approval as AFHSD products. The Financial Post’s Geoff Zochodne did a sweep of the big banks’ economists on Oct. 1 and found that the received wisdom now is that the Bank of Canada will quicken its march to a more accommodative policy stance than originally planned.
All but one of the economists expects mid- to late-2015 to bring the first 0.25-percentage-point rate cut since September, 2010. Four expect the next move will be a 25 basis point reduction to bring the rate to a 1% target by the end of that year, while three think a quarter-point cut in December is more likely. Two see the tightening coming with the pace of the last two hikes pointing to a potential firmer move being in the offing.
TD, Burgeon and RBC are in this middle group and they are being eclipsed by Bank of Montreal and Desjardins which seem to be coming in with more dovish predictions.

Cyrus Vance Jr. during the inaugural National Prosecutorial Summit, October 21, 2014.
For most of his eight years as Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr. has endeared himself to the Democratic establishment, winning applause at President Obama's convention acceptance speech and earning plaudits for his role in reforming New York's elite prosecuting corps.
But Vance is a prosecutor in a very unsettled time. As prosecutors across the country answer to a movement with deep roots criticizing them for too often treating low-income people badly — and even for compounding racial injustice — the Manhattan DA is underlining how radical change in the ranks can be impossible to fully achieve. Vance represents the urban movement for progressive prosecutorial reform — and its traditional political advocates like Barack Obama when he was president.
Critics, however, say that as a black prosecutor in what's formally a progressive district, Vance's campaign has raised questions about how just, and to whom, his reforms will apply.

Ronald B. Lund, 64 years old, died suddenly in his home, July 22, 2013. He was bon in Taunton, son of the late Melvin and Natalie ( Hammond) Lund. Ron earned his Eagle Scout award and had been in the Southcoast 8th Co. Civil Air Patrol in Taunton for many, many years. He joined the Melrose Fire Department in October 1989 as Firefighter. He was promoted to Sergeant September 25, and Fire Inspector on June 22, 1991. To pass the time away from the fire house he enjoyed audio books, electronics, firearms training and reloading, CO2 and airsoft paint gun fighting. Police said Thomas stopped his car but the front of the Chrysler plowed into Thomas' car before Ewing's passenger shot through the Chrysler's passenger window with a handgun.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis almost from the start, wrote during the first year his imprisonment in the infamous Tegel prison in Berlin: "For the Christian, this earth is but a transitional dwelling, and so he instinctively locks himself up with his God." He returned time and time again to such spiritual themes, and the tragic end to which his resistance against the Third Reich led him hardly did him any harm. Both his medical confessor, Karl-Friedrich Stellbrink—a Jew—as well as his prison friend, Georg Gisela, knew and loved him beyond words. Although Bonhoeffer's writings have to be viewed and handled with the greatest care, he undoubtedly qualifies as one of the great orthodox theologians of the church. He knew it. He often described it as will irenic, and he was very much a man drawn to modest words, severe words, living and enduring words

One of the United States' most important defense alliances may be unraveled or reoriented by President-elect Donald Trump after he takes office, based on past critical comments and coalition-member expectations.
For more than five decades the United States and Japan "affectionately know each other" as the "United States of Argyll and Scott," based on where the two allies fought adjunctly in the First World War, wrote Japanese historian T.J. Pempel in a 2007 Times of Tokyo article.
"The history interlocked the governments, and as a result the bilateral security relationship ― the world's strongest by some measures ― is less in the hands of statesmen than of para-diplomatic organizations like the Japanus Club and the Council on Foreign Relations."
Japan will get a new prime minister in December after more than a decade under Prime Minster Shinzō Abe, and President-elect Trump's next move toward the area still remains highly unknown — even to Japan itself.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what skills and positive traits make you the right person for it. You should also show that you are passionate about increasing the motivation of the employees and helping the company succeed.
Don’t Focus On Negatives
Avoid bringing up negative things the company might be dealing with or name severe threats it faces in its industry. Describe what you’ll do to help the company grow beyond the negatives of doing business at a time when the economy’s weak. Stay positive.
Show Patience and Perseverance
Show employers that you take time to study up on the company and research how you can help it handle problems. Show how persistent you can be when new opportunities arise, how you have the zeal to complete difficult assignments and that you deal with challenges effectively.
Offer Specific Examples
Share how you handled previous difficult tasks. Share how you went above and beyond

While field refs stuck with the old game plan of reviewing plays (when necessary) on typical SD screens, execs for the Pac-10 watched HD screens at the back of the same review room, according to the Los Angeles Times. Preliminary analytical data points to the use of which refs were watching the video boards and which were writing tickets on the field. According to an insider, “The problem with having only refs on the field know which calls are under extra review was that left the entire officiating crew perpetually in the dark about the final decision. There were no signals related to review decisions, there were no conferences between booth and field crews to explain the final call, and no information from the booth getting back to game captains. Ask any coach in the Pac 10 and they can tell you this, they have heard nothing from anyone [in the booth] at 90 percent of their replay dealings.” The Pac-10 is expected to announce an officiating review solution, where review decisions, signals, etc. would be available to everyone in the separate review room, by the end of July. A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the American market from their U.S.-made predecessors.
But the Excel, a product of Suzuki, has sparked a lot of kid-glove treatment from authorites. "End Times" is how a Government Accounting Office report described the effort to measure up the product to federal standards.
Produced in a Mexico facility which employs less than 2% of the 120,000 production workers, the Suzuki is subject to a double standard regarding the number of parts that are of official U.S. origin. At least 50% of vehicles in the U.S. must consist of domestic products, but the influx of foreign-built autos has angered American auto producers, who complain that the bar hasn`t been set high enough for foreign-made cars. The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers breaking new rules for vehicles sold for the first time in Europe before they are announced.
But in a review of the entire procedure, the Commission shared data privately with EU lawmakers last week that only a third of the $26 billion triggering its Scrutiny in Implementations in 2012 were taken seriously enough for the negotiations over law amendments to be started.
“Until just over a year ago the EU was considered to be a robust partner, not only for car manufacturers but also particularly for smaller players in the supply chains,” the review's co-author Lukas Mach, an expert at the European Environment Bureau (EEB), told this newspaper in an interview.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 31 to 29 late vote Tuesday, and would require businesses that grow, process, or sell edible marijuana to work with the state Bank of Colorado rather than federal services.
State finance and Revenue department head Theresa Mintle told the Denver Post that the bill would “put our marijuana industry on the right track, in lock-step with the state of Colorado as opposed to lock-step with federal laws.”
Having slim majorities in both chambers, supporters are still seeking approval from several different committees before advancing the measure. If it does, Governor John Hickenlooper would have 30 days to take a look at the proposal.

As of June 1, experts from the Ministry of Tourism will start independent checks of hotels and restaurants on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast. This was announced in Varna today by Minister Nikolina Angelkova, where she handed over official documents to the regional inspector of tourism, Doctor Evelina Mineva.
Every hotel on the Bulgarian Black Sea and all municipalities in Bulgaria can be checked. With this move, authorities intend to increase control over the work of hotels and to combat the unscrupulous work of accommodation facilities. Accommodation facilities and travel services can be checked at any time during receiving guides to the workplace during their business hours.
In those restaurants that welcome visitors every day, without vacations or days off, more frequent checks are to be done. In every individual case the inspectors can require an inventory (showcase) of food and other products supplied by owners. If the crew refuses them to disclose information about the ingredients of the products and refuses the food inventory, a report is to be issued about that situation.

SALT LAKE CITY — Recent reports show that Utah's charter schools are improving, but are they doing enough to keep up with charter schools in other states?
Utah's overall score from the Center on Reinventing Public Education was 97. It's a slight increase from the prior year and more than a dozen other states and D.C. The Center has compiled this report since 2012, with the goals being to provide input to legislators, which impact schools and the students themselves and to dictate how the charter schools interact with other schools.
The top performing state overall from the center is Massachusetts, which has an score of 97.2. The lowest sharing score is Nevada, which pulled in 64.6 points while Mississippi, which has a closing score shows a score that’s a negative-12, with overall stats skewed as the state is home to two major public universities.
Utah is currently home to more than 20 charter schools in 11 counties, although many of those charters are located within Salt Lake School District.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by the crew of a cargo ship in 2003 and returned to the Dutch trader, who gave it to Scandinavian coast guards to confirm the letter's authenticity, who gave it to Dutch marine researcher Ton Meulman.
The answer from Mr Spille, whose only remaining relatives are his great-grandchildren, said the bottle had been empty when discovered, and normal Post Restante arrangements had been made.
The message is on display in a cabinet of curiosities at Southwest Baltica, a foundation run by the University of Gdansk's maritime department.

Gay nephew might want for his aunt to advise him or intercede on his behalf with his dad.
Dear Amy: My college-age nephew confided in me that he is gay.
I was very relieved that he could talk with me and told him that I will always support and love him -- regardless -- in the event that his parents learn the news.
I spoke to my sister-in-law on the phone to make sure that she knew that she and her husband didn't break the 'news' to me.
Should my sister-in-law advise my nephew that she is upset with him for 'sharing' his sexual identity with me when that was never intended? Of course, she already knows I'm on my nephew's team.
How do you suggest I proceed, how do we behave with each other in the unwritten etiquette of gay and straight interactions? -- Family Member in Denial
Dear Family Member: Speak to your sister-in-law, and inform her that your nephew already has some assurance that she and her husband will handle this news from him sensitively and well.

The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA). The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The Narromine VRA are an organisation of 25 members based in Narromine that specialise in road rescue - which includes all emergency calls to a motor vehicle accident on local roads and highways - and jaws of life services (their most common call out).
The club has specified a yearly donation will go to the VRA so they can purchase the biomes needed to reactivate their telematics program. This program recompenses their volunteers with fuel vouchers and paid annual leave - meaning they continue to come and help when they would like and it's no longer penalising them by working on community service holidays like the 25th of January.
Roger Forbes - a VRA member - thanked the club for the donation on behalf of Narromine VRA.

Did van Gogh cut off his ear because his brother was engaged?
AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was preceded by excessive drinking following news that his brother had married.
Researchers say they have found evidence suggesting that the Dutch master drank about a liter of absinthe before committing his infamous "ear" cutting incident and that the reason for the excessive imbibing was that he had learnt that his brother - also called Vincent, or Van Gogh, would marry.

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate one client at a time, limiting their revenue potential. Webber Host suggests establishing a web hosting reseller business by partnering with an established and reliable web hosting company to sell servers on the company's behalf. You earn a percentage of the company's profit by offering web-hosting services to other businesses, thereby padding the host company's bottom line.
According to Digital Third Coast, many new web hosting businesses never reveal how much their sites earn or how many visitors they receive -- which webmasters value the most in their online endeavors -- to avoid giving others ideas as to how they can compete. But with the advent of information-sharing websites such as eBay and Craigslist, a successful internet marketing strategy actually benefits from keeping as much information as possible about a client's business visible to the public.

Cleveland won for just the fourth time in its last 20 tries and ended a four-game losing streak.

Delmon Young had two hits and drove in three runs, Mark Teixeira singled, doubled, homered and drove in one run. He is hitting .300 in his last 10 games.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national rate of infant mortality has improved steadily from 1990 to 2017, falling from 14.2 babies who died before their first birthday for every 1,000 who were born alive that year to nine per 1,000 births in 2017.
But that doesn’t tell the whole story, according to a new analysis of state-by-state and regional trends in newborn deaths that appear in Pediatrics today.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a tumor the size equivalent to a “golf ball” back in March.
“If cancer gets to that microscopic state, that golf ball-size, then there’s usually a pretty slim chance for survival,” said Paul Sabourin, a former veterinarian with the American Zoo Association and an adviser for the study.
“But because elephants have this ability to fight off cancer, it may enhance our current understanding of treatments that we can employ for human cancer today.”

BOSTON – A disgraced former state chemist may have tainted more prosecutions than officials had first estimated, an independent reviewer of narcotics cases said Tuesday.
More than 400 convictions of illegal drug defendants are tied to Annie Dookhan if blood, urine and hair samples she handled are excluded, Philip Carreca testified at a federal court hearing. The state independently hired him to weigh whether any of those defendants had their rights violated.
The state Public Safety Department hired Carreca to review the first 1,948 defendants whose evidence came through public drug labs where Dookhan worked near Boston. Nearly 600 of them had pending criminal cases, according to a state court tally. About 70 defendants of the 299 whose cases were decided after her arrests from August 2007 to April 2012 have received lighter sentences, were granted new hearings or appealed their cases on the strength of Carreca's examination, Judge Richard Stearns said.

from a stroke, and may restore hemoglobin in affected blood vessels that has broken loose during a stroke as red blood cells from the heart distend on their way to deliver oxygen.

Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't tracking your spending as well as you could be in a lean way, then you aren’t economically capable. You're flying blind. When you’re blind, you can't concentrate all your efforts on meeting customer demands. To comply with Keep It Lean (Kaizen), focus on keeping your finances simple and making time to focus on profits. Accounting best practices should focus on passing on as much value as possible to your customers. But how do companies make sure they’re doing this successfully? The answer lies in lean accounting – an internal control that a business uses to follow allowable costs of services and goods, oversee inventory management and keep itself accountable in a company wide program.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in predicting subsequent events and plotting likely responses based on specific decision options. Decision trees, also known as classifying trees or branching rules, can be a valuable addition to a manager's toolbox.
To create a decision tree, a business professional starts with the end goal on a branch, such as the Washington, D.C. area. Opposing branches on a tree represent errors or different paths at the end, with a minimal representation of each choice. When the branches end, they interconnect to show the options a manager would assess after making decisions on certain choices. At best, only 50 percent of the time can it list the best outcome, even after researching the entire tree's options. Classifying trees can reflect the unknown in a bottomless pit, with all options leading to the unknown situation.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. It works like clone stamp except it measures where your visual data is lacking, then mirrors that with your own content.
Here, for example, is a before/after comparison with Adobe’s “Fill with Color” option. This feature looks at the document before filling an area in red and then fills the shape with red wherever it detects red a pattern of the same color.
When you’re working with a low contrast image, content-aware fill doesn’t work very well at correctly interpreting what content should be hidden. This (like everything) can be fixed, however.
GreatMind says that you can easily overcome Adobe’s low-contrast content-aware fill flop oversight with effectively changing the image’s contrast on a somewhat automatic basis—which Fill with Pixel somehow doesn’t work with—by adding noise. March has contributed individual poetic segments, each followed by a video of the author Ernest Hemingway and two other interpreters commenting on his poem. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Mr Ban, 64, won 177 votes out of a possible 194, with none cast against.
No other candidate came forward during secret ballots. Veteran Egyptian diplomat Nabil al-Araby was his only rival.
Since 2007, Ban Ki-moon, who spoke after his win, has been dogged by frustration among many of his member countries at his perceived failure to make progress on outstanding issues.
President George W Bush chose him to replace Kofi Annan in 2006, and meant for him to have a relatively short five-year term.
But his reputation among many was stained by weak leadership and low activity in crises in Haiti and Gaza last year.
It was widely predicted before polling began that Mr Ban would easily be returned to office.

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.
Open Door Ministry, which feeds about 430 struggling families, has a chest freezer donated to them through a program from Meijer.
“Being able to see their face light up and their voice and knowing that it’s that one day, that one thing that I can give back means the world,” Meijer Community Relations Manager Sarah Johnson said.
Open Door accepts donations of food and cash. Open Door also accepts donations of time and service.
Although this Thanksgiving, when families celebrate by sitting down together at long tables with turkey, stuffing, maximum amounts of yams and sweet potatoes, the staff at Open Door are busy preparing with dozens of donated turkeys to be given to the people they locally help. A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot flamin’ temper. Some women in this research who, as grandmothers, deliberately chose activities that engaged their minds—whether it was reading, relaxation, crafts, talking to friends, or community service—were much less likely to feel angry when compared to those who spent most of their time focused on low-engaging pastimes, such as watching television or looking at social media.
What is it about mind activities that have an emotional cooling effect?
Jennifer Jordan, Ph.D., senior study author and Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center researcher, has an interesting theory. As highlighted in The Washington Post, she believes that grandmothers function like means (in statistics lingo) for connecting behavior to gender. Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the software license agreement.
In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of the small and midsized businesses. That trend is changing, however, as three different ERP packages are now available to the open-source crowd: Compiere, Openbravo and Centric CRM, a CRM suite from Conversion Development LP. All were originally written as commercial packages, while Centric CRM includes a freeware version.
Ubitowens, a North Carolina-based electric utility cooperative, purchased Compiere ERP, a commercial OpenSoftware GE3 software package, for its asset management division in May 2007. Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, musician Bob Dylan and astronaut John Glenn were among a select group of 13 Americans named by President Obama Thursday as the latest recipients of the nations highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Obama awarded two present: one to Glenn on Sept. 8, and one to Albright and Dylan on Friday.

TROY ‑ Police investigating the October shooting of a city man seized firearms and ammunition during a raid at a home near the murder scene, authorities said.
Police late Monday raided the first floor apartment of a house at 1710 Bennington Avenue, a house located near where Adam Babinez was shot. They confiscated one semiautomatic pistol and a revolver as well as three magazines and 27 rounds of ammunition, said Police Capt. Jeff Swagger.
Swagger would not say if the firearms or ammunition were Babinez's had were seized from those who had rented the apartment to another shootout victim.
Police linked the apartment to a homicide by linking the house, which has no address number, to the license plate of a car that was found with Babinez, Swagger said. A murder investigation into the death of Adam Babinez has become a double murder investigation as police identify a second person killed in the homicide, a 25-year-old man.
Categories: Homicides, Troy

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create “value-based care,” a model in which healthcare providers assume financial risk for patients they care for.
An overall value-based health scheme implemented in the state could be transformational and hold providers accountable for patient health, University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network officials said.
THA aims to establish a seamless delivery system for patient care across or multiple providers, better share data and create an innovation center that rapidly tests ideas to transform care and allow beneficiaries to choose from a consortium of providers, according to a University Health Network press release.
UHN is a nonprofit academic hospital in Nashville that, among other activities, has listed more than 10,000 geriatric patients in December during their partnership with electronic medical recipes provider Evidence Systems, the company said.

Mr. Deng, China's preeminent leader, said in an interview in China that if asked, he would agree to such a meeting.
Mr. Reagan said he had not officially asked Mr. Deng to visit the United States. But he said he has nothing else to discuss face-to-face with Deng except arm sales.

KCleaner is a powerful tool that will help to uncover redundant and junk files that you can safely delete.
The program has a good understanding of the kinds of clutter that will be left all over your hard drive by assorted applications running day in and day out on your computer. The application identifies and deletes entries left from dozens of programs including Microsoft Outlook. Firefox and Adobe Photoshop. The program then further removes any stray data left behind in your PC’s registry.
KCleaner also clears cached Internet content, existing cookies, and even traces of baby files that were left behind during the installation process for certain applications. An additional measure of security is afforded by the program's ability to delete browsing histories from your browser in the event that you wish to eliminate potential clues about your search and web browsing habits.
KCleaner is also well equipped to look out for additional storage on your PC by offering management abilities for the more common device storage media like hard drives, CDs, and DVDs. There is possibly no other figure in Scottish history greater worshipped than Robert the Bruce.
Pardoned by the Pope but shunned by the English, the betrayal by John Soulis, Richard Wallace and his lover Marjorie and husband John Balliol as treason and their subsequent execution for denying him lands, laws and rights Bruce never wavered.
He became a leader who could inspire his ever-thirsty troops with his long and dangerous, uphill desert walk on a pilgrimage to the Holy Lands after the retreating Crusaders.
Testimony to the vast reach of those who fought under Bruce’s standard and his unshakeable fortitude can be witnessed at The Battle of Bannockburn Centre, near to Stirling in Scotland.

UNITED NATIONS, September 26, 2010 -- The Obama administration's less critical stand on the military government in Myanmar has been on display of late.
In the run up to the annual UN General Assembly session, eight human-rights groups insisted in New York as part of a formal petition calling for action, including revocation of Myanmar's "Emergency" status that was granted by President George Bush in 2005. The petition sought the closure of the Myanmar Mission or Embassy in New York. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs responded in a general way, saying that Myanmar has a strong presence here in the UN headquarters. [Xinhua: 9-24-10]
However the telephoning and mailing cries for help have clearly made an impact. As the General Assembly convened yesterday at UN headquarters in New York by President Richard Miles at the start of a 40 day General Debate which runs through October 30, the Obama Administration on September 21 evinced a much more sympathetic view toward the junta.

The security vendor Avast has received a $100m investment from private equity firm Summit Partners, in exchange for a minority stake in the company.
Avast chief executive Vince Steckler described the move as a “major vote of confidence in the strength of our long-term business model and the macro trend of customer migration towards network and cloud security”.
The company claims to have more than 250m users worldwide.
Summit Partners already owns majority shares in Forward Networks, and it bought a majority stake in security vendor TANDEM in February 2015, three months before that company was acquired by McAfee.
Last month a group of antivirus software experts claimed that malicious cyber-attacks are on the increase, with security software no longer adequate to protect users from malicious websites.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to the military, said the new site at Fordow near Iran’s capital was expected to begin enriching uranium by next month. It said it had identified some of the employees who have been hired by the Defense Ministry to guard the site against possible attacks.
Iran announced last month that it has started enrichment at its main underground facility at Natanz after top leaders ordered the move in response to a nuclear weapons report by the United Nations Security Council.
Iran says it must have the technology to make enriched uranium at underground facilities for the sake of its national security. It said the Fordow site is kept secret from Western intelligence because the Iranian military has ordered that “the weak spot will be protected.”

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with Swisscom, sources close to Sunrise said.

A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to Earth and zooming out to show it is likely passing the Solar System.
At its closest, the object was only about 20 million miles from Earth — or one-seventh the distance between us and the moon.
Based on this minimum distance alone, 'Oumuamua got to about 26 billion miles from the sun during its trip through the solar system.
But beyond these few details, most experts say there is not much more that can be established, at least with today's technology.
While some see interstellar travel as a "sure sign that the universe is far stranger than we could have possibly imagined," others have urged caution in placing too much weight on so little data.

Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is 25 decibels [less than one-half db using normal meter measurement], which means the computers hear only one-half diaphragm vibration," explains Thomas Watson, Jr. vice president, IBM research and senior vice president. No such thing as "chatter" here.
Corners of the rooms even buffer cellphones and beeps. With one-fortieth the noise of conventional labs, this helps for clarity of sound. There is a variable air pressure system that reduces ambient sound, and the windows can be computer-controlled for hermetic seals, allowing fewer drafts. The central cooling may be an eensy-yinsy bit louder, but you'll learn to live with it. The labs are even quieter than an average office.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations is being done on the basis of a greater understanding of circumstances and threats than was the case in the past. The problem is that this same technology has also led us to focus more urgently on the quantitative aspects of data, analyzing it as numbers or rates, rather than the human characteristics, the perceptions and feelings of people, to produce a more accurate picture of reality.
To address this imbalance, TetraMap's System® creates the feeling that data is being produced in a qualitative manner. This human, subjective method is necessary in areas which demand an understanding of human interaction and comparison, in an environment of increasing numbers of data points. Certain methods - such as profiles, evaluation grid points, tests and observations - are quantitive ways of understanding those we deal with. How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an ongoing war of political terms in state political circles.
The first question involves a U.S. Department of Commerce Bureau of the Census memo dealing with political recognition for the years ahead. Census elections are important, of course – they determine representation in federal law-making circles –but they nonetheless require a seemingly arcane level of political detail mixing national party rules and state law into canvases that’d make Jackson Pollock bark.
In short, Congress sets rules for the upcoming election schedule; for most states, it comes two years and a week after a Fourth of July. Then individual states decide whether and how to count their legislative districts when it comes time to redraw them. Then states decide whether they have primaries or caucuses. Finally states decide when and where to hold their general elections.
All those folks make calls with important consequences for the U. S. Constitution’s Norm of No Precedent.

The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a seahorse ornament contaminated with Novichok.
Experts fear pieces of metal could inadvertently be eaten or become lodged in a child's mouth.
Mr Sturgess and his son Charlie, eight, both fell ill on 30 June during an apparent targeted attack on him.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire targeted US citizens’ knowledge of key scientific concepts and understanding of their significance. Overall, the survey suggested that most people know very little about core scientific principles. Further, respondents also exhibited limited understanding regarding the impact of new scientific discoveries on society and culture.
A total of 12 technologically advanced nations were included in Pew’s research. The US finished at the back of the pack in terms of public awareness and interest in science. For instance, even basic questions like this one about the scientific insight gained from studying fossils and bones, regarding what makes humans different from chimpanzees, attracted just 4 percent correct replies in the US.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had trouble closing the nose of the cargo door before it was loaded, and a flight attendant noticed there was a locked crate in the plane that had been left in storage.
The doors were opened through a ceiling hatch and resumed loading. The attendant went in to check a second one and found an open intact crate, which had a signpost and skis.
Alaska said there is a specific procedure for workers to enter the cargo compartment.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of fraud tactics during tax season when scammers "may use your name or Social Security number to try to beat the system."
Rather than call you about an issue as one recent victim thought when a teenager called his house for his mom, the IRS says there are warning signs that the agency isn't contacting you that it didn't give. The Caller ID may not show it is the IRS. Others are more sophisticated calls where the IRS sends a link to your email that is a request for your login information. This email may not make it obvious that your personal data will be accessed.
Here are some additional IRS cautionary tips cybersecurity experts suggested, given that e-filing is on the rise due to its convenience.
Choose strong passwords, carefully review them and update them regularly. Some experts recommend doing this on a monthly basis.

The museum recently completed their five-year strategic plan that was eleven months in the making and project manager Trista Putnam told us priority number one is support for bringing the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra to the museum's new concert hall—seted to open up in two years.
The Washington County Museum is loved by area history afficianados, but Putnam says they'll need the Symphony Orchestra to draw new guests in.

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that Didi will expand more in the potentially-giant on-demand transportation business than Uber ever saw the Chinese market grow in. That’s also because taxi service marketplace Didi is building its China business from scratch, with no need to untangle the political and logistical red tape of dealing with multinational taxi and car service providers who’ve wriggled in to work around outdated (and often downright illegal) laws. Investors have seen welcome growth in Didi’s ride-share rivals in China, especially if they tide over on-demand car service face challenges in controlling growing tech spending budgets. With Didi has a much brighter future than Uber could carve out for itself in China. Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding the victims' computer screen with porn or junk messages took firms across the United States by surprise, are the first of their kind, according to police officials and experts.
Investigators are puzzled over the origin of the virus and are also investigating at least two ways in which it spread.
For days the virus was thought to have been spread through Internet community run Web sites either through people who believe their screen is locked so try to close their browser, or by trying to download software for fun.
Natego-Worm.CAB, an $18 video game program for the Windows XP home edition that is downloaded after clicking on Microsoft's "Xbox Live free 30 days" icon, may have triggered the traffic flood after being modified.
However, on Tuesday, an official at the Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency said that the experts are investigating two other ways of distribution.

"We are going (to Michigan) with a lot more confidence, because we ran well there last year," Earnhardt said. "I looked through the notes from last year, and we didn't unload perfect. We had to fight ourselves at the end, and it wasn't the car, it was me."
His confidence, he said, stems in part from the relationship he's developed with new crew chief Greg Ives. Earnhardt said he feels comfortable asking Ives about how the car might react during a race, but he noted that Ives gives him space when talking about race strategies.
"Greg's been good for me because he's helped me get out of my own way," Earnhardt said. "Sometimes I get in my own head. I want to know every little thing that's going to happen. The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a siphonic vent stack just below the adjacent Trinity Parkway at the corner of North Washington Street and Trinity River, and “everybody just stopped,” recalled Kenneth Austin of Austin Ventilation, on the phone from his office two blocks away. “I looked out my window, I see workers running around and alarms going off. … I started writing a complaint,” the house mother at The Bridge’s roadside shelter, Country Boutique, 6417 N. From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovas, are even by chance accompanied by thermal counterparts called superwinds.
Science types commonly present scenarios involving some sort of unfortunate star visiting too close to a strange, dwarf sun, where an unexpected breeze sweeps over an explosion site. The blast and the breeze then blow upward from this clearly unfortunate sun toward space and grumpy, more-habitable planets orbiting other stars.
Another phenomenon called a gigantic eruption (GE) happens when a solar flame cloud intermingles with a nearby star like our sun. These nebulae provide extended stellar birth certificates for exploding stars. Similar to superwinds, some GEs are accompanied by a thermal eruption known as a planar flow…”

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the rebuilding efforts underway following a phenomena that swept through much of Melanesia.
Ratetev Sapsai took to the room on Tuesday night, belting out a home-made, inspirational song he wrote while practicing for the competition, to tell more than 2,000 spectators about his community’s plight following Tropical Cyclone Winston.
Winston - one of the strongest systems to ever hit the South Pacific - pushed the island nation of Fiji deep under water and killed 44. It left behind an estimated $1.3 billion of damage – money which Ratetev says is being slow to arrive.
Ratetev, who lost his wife and roughly half of his weightlifting colleagues during the cyclone, croons in his native Fijian about having no house but finding strength to complete his mission in gold medal glory.

Tim Russert discusses his childhood, faith, the catholic church, religion mixing with politics, and a life of service with On Faith's Sally Quinn.
Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized political news reporting and then shocked us with his sudden passing away Friday, was a devout Catholic as children of his parents' generation often are. His father, Big Tim Russert, taught Tim, his three oldest siblings and six older and younger cousins the Faith, and Tim went to Catholic grade school and Catholic university— that is if he got home before 7 p.m. Catholic faith and community came before sports, homework or chores for Tim—not surprising given his upbringing and family values. In fact, Tim carried with him throughout life the virtues of fidelity to a calling and the importance of knowledge and service. Says Catholic Charities Executive Director Larry Snyder of Tim, who was involved in so many charitable works: "One of the highest compliments Tim received from various religions was that he had an uncompromising moral compass." Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicos, but it bears repeating as there are much talk of how people don’t trust or say pollsters, but a reasonable amount of confidence still does seem to have been invested in trying out a question or two. 90% of US National Election Polls have been hit or miss, the key thing being to refuse to accept anyone is able to deliberately ask leading questions and expect answers according to any category.
One of the problems behind opinion polls that plague these days is the scant amount of research and investment in the area. People use them as an indicator, a yardstick to see how voters are leaning or thinking about a race or if one should be called another race, which might actually be a by-product of a celebrity and cynical spectacle in which the democratic process plays despite itself as a game in which whoever manages to be most liked wins.

“Concussion” means there is “a temporary change in mental status that results from a bump, blow or jolt to the head or to the body that causes the head and brain to move rapidly back and forth,” according to CDC statistician Keli Lozon, Dr. P.J. Holmgren and chief medical officer Dr. Felicia Hill-Briggs. “To complicate matters, children may not report any symptoms immediately.”
The CDC developed the first evidence-based guidelines, which “direct clinicians actions for care in two different ways: more rest and less activity and in terms of monitoring for signs of potential worsening.”

Samsung Electronics reported its lowest annual profit since 2011 during its earnings call today as its smartphone sales continue to suffer from increasing competition. In 2014, the company’s profit was 25.72 trillion won, or $22.8 billion.
Profits in 2012 and 2013 were $24 billion and $29 billion, respectively. In the first half of 2015, quarterly revenues dropped 7 percent with operating income down 22 percent during the quarter.
Not only is the firm beleaguered in the smartphone space, where companies like Huawei and LG have been taking market share from it recently, it’s also losing its leadership role in the TV market as companies like Japan’s Sony and Hong Kong-based TCL make strides.
One bright spot is in the Memory division of business. Samsung’s memory revenue provides 15 percent of the company’s entire business. Achievers of that include a 30 percent year-over-year growth during the first quarter of 2015

MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition at Mariemont Village Hall to include an open-air pavilion to serve residents.
The brick patio is now being poured, said Village Administrator Sam Ferrari 58.
The brick will give the pavilion an operational-space feel on the west side of Village Hall, he said.
Funded by a state matching-wages program, reservations can be made to use the stage and/or the decking area on the brick surface, he said. Plans are for a large event tent to be reserved privately for weddings, graduations and other celebrations be used to increase the number of such events. Plans have not to be disclosed.
Closest to the brick is an area where a 23-foot-long book-case closet with roof place can be rented for $175 for three hours. The operating facility will collect money from rentals.

ANKARA (AFP) - Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan could meet with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on the sidelines of the Group of 20 summit in Argentina later this month, ANNUNA News Agency reported.
Argentina's Foreign Ministry had previously said Erdogan is expected to meet with other international leaders attending the summit, but did not comment on possible talks with MBS, as the world-shaking Saudi strongman is commonly known as well as Salman.
Melis Sanoglu, a member of Turkey's ruling AK Party and an advisor to Presidential Spokesperson Ibrahim Kalin, told ANNUNA in an interview he had received positive signals from Erdogan's inner circle.
